annotation.TEXT: Centaur Man is another who can be classified under the "obnoxious" category. While his spread shot is easy to avoid, his random teleporting and time stop moves are both incredibly annoying to deal with. This is especially considering his time stop is virtually instantaneous, meaning the only way to really avoid it is to guess when he's going to use it.

Devil Torch acts almost like a stronger version of Holy Water from Castlevania. The initial shot it fires doesn't do any damage, but the resulting fire-wave does. It's actually kind of a versatile weapon, since not only does it travel along any surface, but it can also go through most forms of shielded enemies.

It's also worth noting that every single boss in this game only takes 2 points of damage from most weapons (with the exception of Knight Man's). Given this, using the buster on a majority of them is almost always a faster alternative.

I really only came here for the new Jet Adapter, but Vertical Draft isn't half-bad. Straight up and down are extremely situation-based trajectories when it comes to Mega Man games, but for what it's worth, this weapon is still quite strong (and has a larger than average range to it).

I recall mentioning a while back that I never got the chance to complete Mega Man 5 or 6. Since then, I've managed to rectify this. Even after beating the originals however, it still made me wonder even more about potential hacks based on these games.

Psycho Impact trades in the original Centaur Flash's damage output for ammo and speed. While it only deals 2 damage to most enemies on the screen, you now have 14 shots instead of 7. It's also much faster and doesn't freeze you in place, essentially giving it rapid fire capabilities.

Time for the main run-down: Mega Man controls the same as he did in the original. The stage layouts, enemies, most of the bosses, weapons, and the locations of the Jet and Power Adapters have all been changed.

That alternate path actually leads to the Energy Balancer. Getting through there is determined by two things: Whether or not you have the Power Adapter, and if you let any of the enemies light those oil fields in the previous rooms (notice that each flame has a number next to it).

These new fan enemies are sadly the closest thing to a gimmick that Wind Man's stage has. The wind they produce is much stronger than in the original, which is now needed to make specific jumps. Either way, this is the only room in the entire stage that they make an appearance in.

Both of these games are actually incomplete for the time being, though Rockman 6 Skype is far closer to a finished state than Innocent. Given such, that's the one I've elected to play during my down-time while waiting for other releases.

The flames themselves are instant death, so the only way to get by them is to make sure nothing lights the oil fields...which is way too much of a chour to do without any of the Robot Master weapons on-hand. I'll pick up the Energy Balancer off-screen for the next part, since there's not much worth showing once you get in there (the path itself basically skips the rest of the level).

The new Jet Adapter is going to make things much easier from here on out. Unlike the original, this version lacks any kind of awkward start-up time of sorts. In turn, this means way more free-range when it comes to flying.
Have I mentioned that I hate these barrel enemies before? Next to the electric spines from Mega Man 3, these are easily some of my most despised enemies in the entire series.

Sadly, there seemingly wasn't much to work with (especially in comparison to the overabundance of MM2 hacks). However, there were in fact two hacks dedicated to finally giving 6 some attention: Rockman 6 Innocent, and Rockman 6 Skype.

Flame Man hasn't really received too much in the way of AI upgrades. In fact, I honestly think he's far easier than he was in the original. His attacks are much slower, and his traditional flame blast is only activated by causing some of his shots to erupt into shockwaves when they hit the ground.

Absolute Zero further demonstrates just how radically different this hack's weapon set is. When used, it creates a form of icy wind that locks horizontally to where it was fired. Almost any enemy that comes into contact with it is immediately frozen, which you can then instantly kill by running into them.

Cyber Gabyoall's are easily one of the more obnoxious enemies in this game. I have no idea how their movements are determined now. Whenever you get on the same plane as them, they just seem to spazz out half the time.

This next section is probably among my least favorite in the game. It's essentially a set of narrow ice paths, which tend to have enemies clustered in spots where you probably won't be able to avoid taking damage (unless you know they're there beforehand). Mercifully, you can skip most of this by melting specific walls if you happen to have the Devil Torch.

Wind Man has now become one of the more obnoxious bosses in the game. His pattern isn't too difficult to deal with, even with his new projectiles. The problem mostly stems from his wind attack. Much like the fans from before, the pushing effect is much stronger. While it doesn't last too long, it can still become annoying if you don't jump at the right time.

Blizzard Man also didn't seem to get much in the way of overly extensive changes, but he still somehow manages to be annoying. I personally blame it on his ice projectiles, which (aside from blending in nicely with the background) form in spots that are very easy to jump into, along with offering little room to avoid them depending on where Blizzard Man himself is.
Power Adapter is virtually the same as it was in the original, which is fine by me. I really can't think of too many ways to modify it (without making it broken, at least).

You can destroy Ben K's spears with a charged shot from the Power Adapter, but the spears themselves move way too fast for it to be reliable. Fortunately, there are a few other ways you can generally deal with them.

A few of the stages manage to maintain some of their trademark gimmicks from the original, but used in other ways. Even then, there's actually quite a few levels in this game that feel rather empty when it comes to this aspect. This is either due to under-utilizing the original gimmicks, or by just being...well, kinda boring. It'll become more evident as this goes on.

The "Gamarn and Gamadayu" mini-boss is more of a pain now. Aside from bombs dropping automatically from the ceiling, the frog itself can now reel you in with its tongue (which causes far too much damage for its own good).
